wiki.text:
A 'blueprint' is a reproduction of a technical drawing, documenting an
architecture or an engineering design, using a contact print process on light-
sensitive sheets. Invented in the 19th century, the process allowed rapid and
accurate reproduction of documents used in construction and industry. The blue-
print process was characterized by light colored lines on a blue background,
a negative of the original. The process was unable to reproduce color or
shades of grey.

Various base materials have been used for blueprints. Paper was a common choice;
for more durable prints linen was sometimes used, but with time, the linen
prints would shrink slightly. To combat this problem, printing on imitation
vellum and, later, polyester film (Mylar) was implemented.

The process has been largely displaced by the diazo whiteprint process and by
large-format xerographic photocopiers, so reproduced drawings are usually called
"prints" or just "drawings".
wiki.title: blueprint
